titlePage.docImprint: Vol. Xxiv — no.36 Richmond, Va. Wednesday, February 11, 1863 price one cent

div1.head:
Richmond Dispatch
by Cowardin & Hammersley.
div1.p:
the Daily Dispatch is served to subscribers at Six and A Quarter cents per Week, payable to the Carrier weekly.
Price for mailing, $4 a year, or $2.50 for six months, in advance.
the Semi-Weekly Dispatch is issued every Tuesday and Friday at $2.00, in advance.
the Weekly Dispatch is issued every Friday, and mailed to subscribers at $1 per annum.
Advertisements published until forbid, will be charged 50 cents per square of eight lines for the first insertion, and 25 cents for each continuance

div3.head: Skirmish on the Rappahannock.
div3.p: On Friday of last week there was a pretty severe skirmish at Rappahannock bridge, between a body of the enemy who had been sent to destroy the bridge and a detachment of Hampton's cavalry.--The enemy had partly succeeded in accomplishing their purpose when our men came upon them, and a brisk fight drove them off, with the loss of four killed, eighteen or twenty wounded, and thirteen prisoners. Our loss, one killed, seven wounded, and two missing. The bridge was not a very substantial one, and can easily be repaired in a few days.

div3.head: From Fredericksburg.
div3.p:
There was nothing of importance from General Lee's army last night.
Our correspondent writes us that nine Federal cavalry deserters came across the river above Fredericksburg Monday, bringing with them nothing more extraordinary to tickle the Confederate appetite for news than the report of Lincoln's death.
This is light material compared with the majority of deserters.
The writer suggests that as Hemlin is half bigger, he would make a good successor to Old Abe.

div3.head: The Exemption bill disposed of in the House.
div3.p:
The House of Representatives yesterday gave the quietus to the Exemption Bill reported from the Committee on Military Affairs, and all the amendments connected therewith.
After expending two weeks in its discussion, and adopting a large number of amendments, the House deliberately defeated the measure by a vote nearly approaching unanimity.
It will be recollected that an act was passed some two weeks ago repealing the most objectionable clauses of the existing exemption law. The action of the House yesterday leaves the bill enacted at the last session in force, except so much of it as has been rescinded by the adoption of the bill repealing the clauses which gave color to discrimination and class legislation.

div3.head: Carrying out the emancipation proclamation.
div3.p: Within that portion of Virginia now occupied by the Federal forces under the notorious Milroy, Lincoln's emancipation proclamation is being faithfully carried out. The following is a copy of an order sent to a lady of Clarke county, by Gen. R. H. Milroy, through the hands of a runaway negro named John Washington, whose wife and children were servants of the lady:

div4.p: --You will release to Mr. John Washington his wife and children, and all other slaves in your possession, made free by the proclamation of Abraham Lincoln.

We understand that Mr. John Washington carried out his mission, not only in taking off the slaves demanded by Milroy's order, but also the fine carriage and horses of the lady upon whom the demand was made.

div3.head: Secretary Benjamin's circular on the raising of the Charleston blockade.
div3.p: The following is a copy of the circular addressed by Secretary Benjamin to the foreign Consuls in the Confederacy:

div4.head: [Circular.]
div4.opener:
Department of State, Richmond, January 31st, 1863. Monsigur Bettancourt, Consular Agent of France, at Wilmington, N. C.
Sir:
div4.p:
I am instructed by the President of the Confederate States of America to inform you that this Government has received an official dispatch from Flag-Officer Ingraham, commanding the naval forces of the Confederacy on the coast of South Carolina, stating that the blockade of the harbor of Charleston has been broken by the complete dispersion and disappearance of the blockading squadron, in consequence of a successful attack made on it by the iron-clad steamers commanded by Flag-Officer Ingraham.
During this attack one or more of the blockading vessels were sunk or burnt.

As you are doubtless aware that, by the law of nations a blockade when thus broken by superior force ceases to exist and cannot be subsequently enforced unless established de novo, with adequate forces and after due notice to neutral powers, it has been deemed proper to give you the information herein contained for the guidance of such vessels of your nation as may choose to carry on commerce with the now open port of Charleston.

closer.signed: J. P. Benjamin, Sec'y of State.

div3.head: Dead.
div3.p:
--Dr. Thomas Fearn, who was one of the Alabama members of the Provisional Congress of the Confederacy, died at Huntsville, Ala., on the 16th ult., of consumption, contracted in the jail of that city, into which he was thrown by the Federal Commander, Gen. O. M. Mitchell when the Yankees had possession of the place.
He was a native of Pittsylvania county, Va., and was 74 years of age. He served as a surgeon in the war of 1812, and during that period dressed the wound of Gen. Jackson.

div3.head: Successful skirmish.
div3.p: --On the 7th inst., Col. Wm. B. Tabb, of the 59th Virginia regiment, Wise's brigade, surprised a party of Yankee cavalry near Olive Branch Church, on the Peninsula, killed seven and captured thirty-six, with horses and equipments.

div3.head: Lacomic.
div3.p:
--Gen. Mitchell, the Federal commander at Nashville, has ordered the property of Dick McCann, the guerilla, to be burnt.
The Chattanooga Rebel says:

q.p: Dick McCann has sent in his compliments to Mitchell. "You may burn and b — d, " says Dick. "but if I don't give you h — l my name ain't Dick McCann. " And Dick's the boy to do what he says.

div3.head: A battery support.
div3.p: --After the recent fighting in North Carolina a Chaplain of a Massachusetts regiment, conversing with one of the wounded of the 3d New York artillery, said to him: "Were you supported by Divine inspiration?" "No," was the reply; "we were supported by the 9th New Jersey."

It is an idle waste of time to attempt to shame the Yankees about their cent and hypocrisy.
The only can't that worries them now is — they "can't take Richmond or Vicksburg."

Specie and Bank Notes.--The premium for specie remains as last quoted, viz; 226 for gold and 210 for silver.
These are the selling rates.
The brokers are paying 5@10 cents below these figures.
We quote Va and M C bank notes at 35 per ct premium; Georgia and S C do at 40 per ct. Exchange on London $25.

Bonds and Stocks.--We note sales of Confederate bonds at 100 ½ and int — payable in the new (7 per ct) Treasury notes; do do (15 M loan) 108 and int; North Carolina eights 116 and int; do do sixes 125, Missouri sixes 120; Va. reg'd stock 100; Richard and York River R R bonds 100 and int; R and D R R stock 105½ Farmers' Bank stock 107½ Bank of the Commonwealth 107½ Traders' Bank 105; Bank of Richmond 80.

Real Estate.--The sales of real estate at auction last month amounted to nearly $234,000. In January last year, to $77,222. Messrs Goddin & Apperson sold at auction, last week, a lot on 18th street, between Broad and Grace--59 by 82 --with a large, old brick dwelling thereon, for $10,230.

Produce and Groceries.--We continue to quote Wheat at $3 40 @3 50 for prime red and white.
Corn has advanced, and readily brings $4 bushel.
Flour — Superfine, $20. Extra.
$22.50 @23; Family, $24. Corn Meal--$4@4.25 bushel.
Tobacco — Market firm; sales of lugs at $10@15, common leaf $15@25, and fine $25@40.
Bacon — Sales at $1.10 for hog round.
Apples--$30@45 barrel, as to quality.
Butter--$1.50 ; a prime article $1 9@1.
Lard--$1 20 Cheese--$1 80 10 Beans--$8@16 bushel.
Onions--$25@10 bushel, and very scarce, Irish Potatoes--$4 50, no Sweet in market.
Seeds — Clover, $28@33; Timobby $7@8 --25 cents lb. Candles--$ lb by the box. Country Soap--75 cents lb, Suger — Brown, 90 cents lb by the barrel; white, $1 50.
Moleses — Recent sales by auction at $7 50 gallon, Coffee--$1 @1 5) lb, by retail.
New Rice--19½ cents lb, by the . Salt-- cents lb. Coal is in the markets at $1 lb.

div3.head: Progress of the war.
div3.p: We give some further extracts from New York papers, of the 6th, for which we are indebted to the politeness of Capt. Philip Cashmeyer:

div4.head: Correspondence between Milroy and Gen. Imboden--threats and Counter threats.
div4.p: The Wheeling (Va.) Intelligencer, of the 31st ult, says that some correspondence between Gen. Imboden, C. S. A., and Gen. Milroy, U. S. A., has been received at the "Executive Department" there by Plerpont, and gives the following resume of it:

Imboden says that Sheriff Trayborn, of Barbour county, was arrested by his order.
He understands that two rebels named Henry Wilson and Henry Bowman were recently murdered in Barbour co. Imboden further understands that 15 citizens of Barbour county have been arrested and confined in this city, and are to be executed is 15 days if Trayhorn is not released within that time.
Imboden informs Gen. Milroy that he will not release Trayhorn, and if the 15 citizens are executed Imboden will execute 30 Union citizens and officers now in his possession.
Imboden says he is "resolved that within the limits of the pretended State of West Virginia he will at all times arrest as dangerous enemies to his State every man he can lay his hands upon who hold any office under the usurped State Government at Wheeling" He says, further, that when he ascertains for certain that Wilson and Bowman have been murdered, he will cause to be executed Lieut. Dawcon, of the 1st Virginia cavalry, and Serg't Atkinson, of the regiment, now in his possession.

Gen. Milroy replies to these threats that he is not in command of any troops in West Virginia, and knows of nobody who has been murdered except in sattle.
Gen. Milroy reminds Imboden that the number of rebels in his possession is much greater than the number of Union men in Imboden's, and that he must not presume so far upon the forbearance and superior humanity of the Federal Government as to put his threat of executing Dawson and Atkinson into execution.
Gen. Milroy hopes that Imboden will not compel him to the painful alternative which the execution of his threat will render inevitable.
Gen. Milroy says in conclusion:

q.p:
"I notice that the Confederate Government is about to offer $100,000 for my head.
Had you not better come down to Winchester and go into the speculation."

div4.p: Wilson and Bowman, the parties alluded to in the correspondence, were killed under the following circumstances: The morning after Shetiff Trayhorn was kidnapped by the rebels a part of a company of Union soldiers started in pursuit, and overtaking Dowman and Wilson upon the road, near the house of the latter, commanded them to halt; instead of halting, they hurried on, and were fired upon and killed.

div4.head: The reorganization of the army of the Potomac--what is to be done for it — departure of Gen. Franklin--the Distrust among the commanders, etc.
div4.p:
A correspondent of the New York Times, writing from the Army of the Potomac, gives a full history of the plans for reorganizing that unfortunate corps, which had gone to the very salvage of utter ruin.
He tells some of the faults to be corrected, and says of the army:

q.p:
It has been taught to care more for men than for principle.
Its heart was right in the first place, but its sentiments have been perverted.
It must now come back to the original object, and the Army of the Potomac must be taught the first duty of the soldier--to hear and obey without questioning.

div4.p:
I have reason to believe that Gen. Hooker meditates a renewal of discipline, and the correction of certain abuses, with a stern and vigorous hand.--He has already commenced it. A general order, issued yesterday, bears unrelentingly upon deserters and upon officers absent without leave.
The latter will find it healthy for their official constitutions to report at once.
Two hundred and fifty deserters were yesterday returned to their several corps with instructions to division commanders to organize at once courts-martial, composed of the ablest officers of their commands, and that these men be tried speedily, and punishment meted out according to the verdicts rendered.
The commander believes that proper vigilance upon the part of subordinate officers will prevent desertions, and the exercise of this vigilance will be required.

It is a matter of record that but one man was ever executed in the Army of the Potomac for a flagrant crime, and that was a case of an attempted desertion to the enemy.
The most earnest and vigilant commanders believe that the power of execution should be confided to the commander in the field.
Senator Wilson's new bill meets this exigency.
Half a dozen officers and a dozen privates executed in each corps in the army for flagrant crimes and misdemeanors would have a boneficial effect.
It would mean something.

There is another point upon which I believe Gen. Hooker means to make improvements, and in fact means to control entirely.
It is in the matter of promotions.
Being at the head of the army, he must necessarily know who he has beneath him, and upon whom he can rely.
Faithful officers will be rewarded.
Men who fight bravely and do their whole duty will be placed literally in "the line of promotion" upon the commander's roster.
He will require that his recommendations be promptly approved.
Faithfulness will not be comprehended in a mere machine like performance of duty.
Alacrity and earnest desire for success in their work are the requisites which entitle officers and men to consideration and approval.

Useless, inefficient, and incompetent officers will probably have a hard time of it. No subordinate who does not respond promptly to the wishes of his commander will be tolerated for an instant.--Any such desiring to get out of the service will have an opportunity to do so, and if not going voluntarily, they will go by disgraceful dismission.
The army will be thoroughly weeded, and vacancies filled from the line and from the ranks.
This is the only thing left.
The army is still immense in numbers and material.
It needs recuperation in spirit and efficiency.
And if Gen. Hooker commands it this he will have.

This army may not be able to move for a month — certainly not until we have better and steadier weather.
But we shall have won a victory at the end of that time by the renewed spirits and discipline which shall prevail, as the result of the vigorous and unrelenting work or reorganization.
This has begun, and will go on until finished.
And then we shall look for better things from the Army of the Potomac.

It may not be in a Republic whose people are educated to the principle of personal independence that we shall ever have an army of soldiers, whose more discipline shall render them capable of being impressed and moulded by the force of one powerful will, as Napoleon sometimes impressed and moulded his armies.
But we may have an army that will readily recognize order and discipline and obedience as the primary principles of its action, and then, with a head to command, it will win victories and crush rebellion.

Let the people of the nation take heart.
They are better off in regard to this army than they think they are. The fighting men in it are beginning to command it. Fair-weather commanders are disappearing.
Disloyalty and incompetency are below par, and patriotism and ability are at a premium.
When we fight again we shall fight to some purpose.

Gen. Franklin took his departure yesterday for Washington, after turning his command over to Gen. Smith.
He was escorted from headquarters by a large number of officers, including the members of his own and Gen. Smith's staff.
His first exclamation on seeing so many officers drawn up to receive and accompany him was, "Good God!
what does this mean?" Prior to leaving he issued an address to the soldiers of the Left Grand Division referring to his past connection with them, counselling them to be faithful to their new commander even as they had been to him, and closing by saying it was not necessary for him to inform them that he did not leave by choice.

This settles the point at issue as to whether Gen. Franklin was relieved of his command peremptorily, or in accordance with a request that he should not be compelled to serve under Gen. Hooker,--Gen. Franklin made no secret of his opposition to the late attempt of Gen. Burnside to cross the Rappahannock.
The Commander-in-Chief, I have reason to know, distrusted the commander of the Left Grand Division, who, I am informed, made frequent charges of incapacity against him to the President, and in other ways attempted to secure his removal.
I can attribute his removal to no other cause than this, viz: His intriguing against, and failure to co-operate with, his General Commanding.

Gen. Franklin is a brave and skillful soldier, popular with both officers and man. But his ardent devotion to Gen. McClellan, to whom he is indebted for his rapid promotion, may have rendered him blind to the virtues of and hostile to any General who might succeed him. If this be true, the interests of the army demanded that he should no longer be retained as a division commander.
General Smith, commander of the Sixth Corps, succeeds to the command of the left Grand Division.
He is the same Gen. Smith who was so unjustly accused of falling from his horse at the battle of Lee's Mills from intoxication.
Though a besom friend of Gen. Franklin--always camping near, and constantly with him — he has showed an antipathy for Gen. McClellan only equalled by Franklin's admiration — He was promoted to the Sixth Army Corps at Warrenton when Gen. Franklin succeeded to the command of the left Grand Division.
Prior to that time he had charge of the First Division of the Sixth Corps, since commanded by Gen. Howe, Gen. Newton succeeds to the command of the Sixth Corps.
There is no officer in the service who is to more regard loyal North.
A Virginian by of living at until the breaking out of the was, having ...and remained true to his allegiance.
The general headquarters were being removed back yesterday to the vicinity of-- Bearcity of feel is doubtless the main reason for the change.
Another terrible rain storm has raged all day, which to-night is turning into snow.

div4.head: The negro regiment bill in the U. S. Senate--opposition to it by Davis of Ky., and Carlisle, of Va.--it is urged by the Republicans as their only hope to crush the rebellion.
div4.p:
The bill for enlisting negroes in the United States service, which has passed the House of Representatives, came no in the Senate on Thursday last.
Mr. Carlisle, of Va., made a motion to strike out the 4th section, (that enlisting negroes,) and made a speech in support of his motion:

He said that there was an impression that this war was waged for other purposes than the restoration of the "Union as it was," and be thought that there was much to give strength to that impression.
He was for the "Union as it was," and believed that there was force enough in the Constitution to preserve the Union.
Force might be employed against the rebellion, but not against loyal people.
If the policy of the war was to be liberty to the slave or death to the Union, then the latter would be the only result attained from the attemp to prosecute such a war. If the Administration had a policy, no matter what, it should be changed, if it was against the will of the people and the people had declared with great unanimity, that this was not a war of subjugation, but to restore the Union and put down an armed insurrection.

Mr. Sherman, of Ohio, (Rep.) was surprised at the opposition to this bill.
We had arrived at a condition where we could not fill up the army with volunteers, and the question was, how should we fill up the army?
Was the Senator from Virginia willing to give up the contest?
Every nation had some kind of a conscription law, and Congress had the power to raise armies.
Mr. Sherman claimed that the question really was, whether we should fill up our and continue the war or whether we should give it up. He urged that the bill, instead of being liable to objection, settled the question referred to by Judge Story, and made the time definite when the term of service began.
He would have had the bill gone further, and made the proper exceptions of these who should be drafted.
The laws of France and Prussia had many wise exceptions, which would prevent many hard cases that would occur under a general law. If we would have fewer political speeches and less talk about the negro, and turn our energies to the suppression of the rebellion; we should soon see good results.--He believed that a proper conscription law, with the necessary limitations, to be the most important law that this Congress could pass.
If no such law was passed, he should despair of success.
If we allowed the armies to dwindle in consequence of party disputes and quarrels about Generals, we might as well give up the contest.
But he did not believe that the people ever would give up this contest until the rebellion was crushed out.
Mr. Carlisle claimed that the decision referred to by the Senator from Wisconsin was merely a dictum of Judge Washington.
The motion to strike out the section was rejected — yess 13, nays 28
Mr. Davis of Ky., (Union,) moved to amend by inserting the word "white," so as to make it read "all able bodied white male citizens."

Mr. Howard, of Minnesota, (Rep.,) was willing to go as far as the furthest in the prosecution of the war; but he wanted to know if it was the desire of the Democratic leaders to indoctrinate that party with the idea that this was an unconstitutional war, and that they were under no obligation to give it support.

Mr. McDougall, of California, (Dem.) did not understand the Senator, or see any reason why he should make a partisan speech at this time.
He would not engage in any party discussion with him. He had endeavored to keep out party politics from discussions in the Senate.
The Democrates of the loyal States were willing to do all that was necessary to strengthen the Government and restore the Union.

Mr. Doolittle regarded this as one of the most important bills that Congress could pass.
It was necessary that the war should he carried on, and the rebellion must be put down by the sword and bayonet, and, if necessary, the whole strength of the country should be called out. He very much regretted to hear this war discussed in a partisan spirit.
There was a time when there were no parties in regard to the war, and he believed that now the people were, without distinction, true to the Government when the real issue was presented of whether this Government should live or die, and a military despotism be erected on its ruins.
If the people, for any cause, should fall to support the Government, and the Southern Confederacy was established, it needed no prophet to foretell the result.
Appeals would be made, first, to the Border States, to join them, and then to Pennsylvania and Indiana, by promising them a monopoly of manufacturing, and, under the lead of such Democrats as James Buchanan, an effort would be made to compel these States to go into that Confederacy.
He believed that to be the original conspiracy to which James Buchanan was a partner.
The friend of Buchanan, Judge Black, has said that if the South went the State of Pennsylvania would go with them.
Mr. Rice, of Minnesota, (Dem.,) asked the Senator if he would express his opinion of Horace Greeley?

Mr. Doolittle said he was perfectly willing to express his opinion.
He regarded the course of the New York Tribune in December, 1860, and also the course pursued by that paper latterly as among the most unfortunate of occurrences, and most mischievous in its tendency.
The New York Herald was regarded as the organ of the Democratic party, and day after day that paper was saying to the people of the South; 'If you go out of the Union and the friends of Mr. Lincoln shall undertake to force the people to submit to his authority, the Democracy of the North will rise in arms, and no Republican soldier shall ever be permitted to leave his State." This was the language of the Herald, until those at the South believed that the Democracy of the North would fight against their country, and that if there was a civil war, it would be in the free States.
The New York Tribune at the same time, almost equally unfortunate, said: "If they want to go, let them go." Here was the New York Tribune, claiming to be the leader of the great Republican party, saying in substance to these Seccessionists: "If you go, the Republicans will not fight you." There two presses, working upon the minds of Secessionists, made them believe that they could enter upon and carry through their attempt to reconstruct the Union without any war.
The bill was recommitted to the committee.

div4.head: Storm at Fortress Monroe.
div4.p: A letter from Fortress Monroe, dated the 4th inst., says:

q.p: The flag of truce steamboat New York arrived to-day at noon from City Point, bringing down 763 Union prisoners from Richmond, in charge of Capt. John E. Malford, of the 3d New York Infantry, who reports that more prisoners are there ready to be exchanged.

div4.p:
News has reached here that an unknown schooner had sunk on Middle Ground, between Old Point and Cape Charles, and that the crew were clinging to the rigging.
Capt. J. M. Hant immediately dispatched a steamer to their relief.
One other schooner is aground near Old Point, and four are aground on the bar between Sowell's Point and the Rip Raps.

The storm was very severe, but has abated.
The steamer Monitor, which was aground night before last, has come off. She is loaded with horses.
As soon as she takes in her coal she will leave for North Carolina.
We hear of two more schooners ashore between here and Cape Henry.
It is expected that all these schooners will be got off by the steam this sent to their relief.
The Southern papers all claim a rebel victory at Mansemond, near Suffolk, on Saturday last.

div4.head: The Dismissal of Fitz John Porter.
div4.p:
The charges, specifications and sentence in the Porter court-martial have just been issued in the shape of a general order.
The following is the language of the President, confirming the sentence of the Court:

The foregoing proceedings, findings, and sentence in the foregoing case of Major-General Pitz John Porter, are approved and confirmed, and it is ordered that the said Fitz John Porter be and he hereby is cashiered and dismissed from the service of the United States as a Major- General of Volunteers and as Colonel and Brevet Brigadier-General in the regular service of the United States, and forever disqualified from holding any office of trust or profit under the Government of the United States.

div4.head: Emigration from England to the United States.
div4.p:
The cotton spinners of Preston, Eng., held a public meeing on the 7th ult., and adopted an address to the New York Chamber of Commerce, setting forth that "many hundreds" of them were anxious to emigrate to America if a free passage could be furnished them.
The address adds:

In this town (Preston, Lancashire,) there are 1,267 spinners and winders, and of that number nearly 800 are totally without employment, in consequence of a great many mills being closed. --Many of them have been closed only twelve months, and those that are working, on account of a very inferior quality of cotton (chiefly Scrat.) being used the operatives scarcely earn sufficient to keep body and soul together.
Such being the state of affairs in Lancashire, the operative cotton spinners of Preston deem it their duty to offer you their humble and sin expressions of gratitude for the noble and philanthropic scheme propounded to release us from our present impoverished condition, and we earnestly hope that the mechanic and cotton manufacturers of the Northern States will land their powerful aid and support to carry out a wise and practical scheme of emigration which we are sure will be beneficial to them and advantageous to the distressed operatives of Lancashire.
If such a scheme of emigration should be carried out it would induce the emigration to America of the flower of the Lancashier operatives
--The Senate was called to order at 12 o'clock by Mr. Hunter, of Va.

Mr. Gen., of S. C., offered a resolution, which was adopted, requesting the President to inform the Senate what proceedings, if any, have been instituted in any of the Courts of the Confederacy to sequester the shares held by alien enemies in the Washington and New Orleans Telegraph Company; and if any decree has been so rendered, whether it includes the profits realized by the company since the separation of these States from the United States; and it such proceedings have not been instituted, the reason why; also, that be inform the Senate the several amounts paid by all the Departments since the establishment of the Government for messages transmitted by said Lee; and whether it be practicable or expedient for the Government to appropriate to its use the shares held in said company by alien enemies.

Mr. Brown, of Miss, presented the position of C. R. Mallory and others, Acting Hidabipmen of the navy, praying for increase of pay on account of the great rise in all the necessaries of life.
Referred to the Committee on Naval Affairs.
A bill, entitled an act to suspend for a limited period the several acts authorizing furloughs to be granted, was presented, and rend the usual number of times.

On motion, the Senate proceeded to consider in Executive session the message of the President transmitting a communication from the Quartermaster General in responded a resolution of the Senate in session to constant etc. of officers serving in cities.
On motion, the Senate adjourned.

div4.head: House of Representatives.
div4.p: --House met at the usual hour, and was opened with prayer by Rev. Mr. Cromley.

Resolutions Introduced and Referred.--By Mr. Rouge, of Ky.: A resolution that whereas information has reached this Congress of the passage by the Congress at Washington, D. C., of a bill for the enlistment of negroes as soldiers in the armies of the United States, which armies are to be engaged in prosecuting the further invasion of the Confederate States of America; and whereas the Constitutions both of the Confederate States and the United States recognize Africans and their descendants as property; and whereas we cannot consent to any change in their political status and condition; Therefore.

Resolved, That the Committee on the Judiciary be instructed to inquire into the expediency of bringing in a bill providing the proper forms for the disposition of all negroes or mulattoes who may be captured from the enemy, in such manner that those of them who are fugitives may be returned to their rightful owners, and those for whom no masters can be found shall be sold into perpetual bondage, for the purpose of raising a fund to reimburse citizens of this Confederacy who have lost their slave property by reason of the interference therewith of the enemy.

By Mr. Curry, of Ala: A resolution that the Committee on Quartermasters' Department inquire into the expediency of such additional legislation as will authorize Post Quartermasters to pay to the persons authorized by law to receive the amount due to decreased soldiers, on the presentation of the proper papers, made out and certified by the commander of the company to which the deceased soldier belonged.
By the same: A resolution that the same committee inquire into the expediency of reporting a bill to pay for horses lost, but not killed, in battle.

By Mr. Lyon, of Ala: A resolution that the Committee on Post-Offices inquire into the expediency of allowing further time to persons holding claims against the Post-Office Department for service rendered in carrying the public matis since the secession of the Southern States, and before contracts were made for transporting the mails, to present the same for settlement.

By Mr. Rails, of Ala.: A resolution that the Committee on Military Affairs be instructed to inquire if any further legislation is necessary to secure the sending of returns to the Adjutant General's office, with a view to expediting the payment of the claims of deceased soldiers.

By the same: A resolution that the Committee on Military Affairs be instructed to inquire into the expediency of so amending the act entitled "An act concerning the pay and allowances due to deceased soldiers approved February 15th, 1862," as to entitle brothers and sisters to receive what is due deceased soldiers in case there is no other person entitled to receive such dues.

By Mr. Garland, of Ark: A resolution that bill No. 28 on the previous calendar entitled "A bill to amend an act to establish Judicial Courts of the Confederate States," be withdrawn from such calendar and placed upon the calendar of this session.
By Mr. Hilton of Fla: A resolution that from and after Monday of the daily meeting of this House shall be 11 o'clock A. M. held on the table.

Bills Introduced.--By Mr. Chiltons.
A bill to allow commutation to soldiers who have been mustered into service for a period of less than twelve months. Referred to Military Committee.

By the same: A bill to grant certain powers to Commissioners of District Courts of the Confederate States.
Referred to Judiciary Committee.
By Mr. Carland, of Arkansas: A bill to provide for punishing persons committing certain acts against the Government of the Confederate States Referred to Judiciary Committee.

By Mr. Royston, of Arkansas: A bill explanatory of "an act entitled an act to authorize the President to accept and place in the service certain regiments and battalions, heretofore raised, approved on the 11th day of October, 1852," Referred to Military Committee.

By Mr. Hilton, of Florida: A bill relating to the organization of the Quartermaster and Commissary Departments.
Referred to Military Committee.

Joint Resolution.--By Mr. Hilton, of Fiz: A joint resolution explanatory of the "act approved Oct. 13th, 1862, to increase the pay of certain officers and employees of the Executive and Legislative Departments." Referred to Committee of Ways and Means.
The Exemption Bill--Mr. Chilton, of Ala., obtained leave to submit the following amandment to the Exemption bill for the purpose of reference to the Military Committee:

q.p: "Be it further enacted That no one who shall be physically able to render military service in the field, or detached service in the hospitals, or to work on Government contracts, shall be exempt from enrollment for military service, who shall have provisions or clothing, or the materials from which the clothing is made, held and hoarded for sale at a future time for the purpose of obtaining an exorbitant price therefor, and who refuse to sell to the Confederate States for the use of the army, or to the families of soldiers in the army, such portions thereof as may be needed for the supply of the army, or the families respectively of soldiers in the service, at a price not exceeding — per cent upon the cost of said article paid by such party hoarding or holding up the same from market as aforesaid; or, if produced by him, then the same per cent, on the cost of production; or who shall refuse to receive in payment therefor, or of any demand due them upon any contract not specially providing for payment in a different currency or in gold or silver, Confederate States Treasury notes."

div4.p: Mr. Chilton also presented the correspondence between the Governor of Alabama and the Secretary of War in relation to exemptions.

The bill being called up as the special order, the question recurred upon the motion of Mr. Dargan to recommit the bill and amendments to the Military Committee, the ayes and noes were ordered, and resulted ayes 40, noes 45.
The House refusing to recommit,
Mr. Chambers, of Miss, moved to reconsider the vote, but subsequently withdrew his motion.
The original bill was then taken up and amended, the principal amendment being that in relation to substitutes, which is as follows:

q.p: And provided further, That no person shall be enrolled who has a substitute in the army, furnished in accordance with orders heretofore issued by the Secretary of War, unless such substitute has deserted, or shall hereafter desert; or has, or shall hereafter, become liable to military duty.

div4.p: This amendment was agreed to — ayes 48, noes 26.

The question then recurred upon the amendment of Mr. Collier to the bill of the committee, as amended in committee of the whole.
On this the ayes and noes were called with the following result — ayes 39, noes 38.
So the amendment was agreed to.
The question then came up on the bill as amended; when

Mr. Johnson, of Va., called the ayes and noes, which were ordered, with the following result: Ayes 14, noes 63.
So the bill was lost.

Mr. Kenter, of La, from the Committee of Ways and Means, reported to the House Senate bill for the appointment of Assistants to the Register in signing bonds and certificates.
The rules were suspended and the bill taken up and passed.

Mr. Holcombs, of Va., from the Judiciary Committee, then called for the next special order, being the bill reported from that committee to authorize and regulate impressments of private property, for the use of the army and other military purposes.
Pending the consideration of the bill a motion to adjourn prevailed, and the House adjourned till 12 o'clock to-morrow.
--The Senate met at 12 o'clock M, and was called to order by the Lieutenant Governor. --Prayer by Rev. Mr. Pestigrew.

A communication was received from the Executive, transmitting a report and accompanying documents in regard to the State Line which were referred to the Committee on Military Affairs and ordered to be printed.

A bill to amend the first, third, fourth, seventh, and eighth sections of "An act to provide for the public defence," passed on the 3d October, 1862. was amended so as to read "first, third, fourth, fifth, seventh, eighth, ninth, and tenth," sections of "An act to further provide for the public defence, " passed, etc., was, after a long and animated discussion, passed.
[The " der to the, bill will give an idea to the whole bill.
It is this: Provided, That if it shall become necessary to make a second requisition upon any county, &c., in the Common wealth, in all such cases such requisition — shall not exceed four per centum of the slave population thereof And provided further, That the last clause of section ten shall not apply to counties which have partially complied with a former requisition, and in such counties the County Courts shall require those persons who have not complied with the requisition made on them to do to before again calling on those persons who have camplied]

Bills Bassed.--A bill to enlarge the powers of the Circuit Courts of the several counties and corporations, in cases of attachments against such residents.
To amend an act entitled "An act to amend section 11 of chapter 29 of the Code, so as to exempt the property of persons in the military service of the State from distress for rent payable in money." passed February 19, 1862.

Resolution.--By Mr. Marshall: To amend the act of March, 29, 1811, entitled "An act to incorporate the American Agency," as that when $56,000 of their capital stock shall be paid in as there directed the said payment may be made by deposit in Confederate money.
And then, on motion of Mr. Dickenson, the Senate adjourned.

div4.head: House of Delegates.
div4.p: --The House met at 12 o'clock. Prayer by Rev. Dr. Jeter.

Bills Reported.--A bill establishing a work house in the city of Richmond.
A bill providing for converting into Confederate States stock the interest due on stock owned by the State in the South-Side Railroad.
A general appropriation bill for the current expences of the State for the year 1863, which, with the tax "bill reported yesterday, will be taken up on Tuesday next and considered from day to day until the Committee on Confederate Relations, submitted a bill directing the sale of the Roanoke Valley Railroad, its rolling stock, &c., provided it meets with the approbation of the Board of Public Works &c.

The bill gave rise to some discussion, and during its pendency the hour having arrived for the further consideration of the bill appointing "general agents and storekeepers for counties and corporations," that subject was taken up and discussed at considerable length, and ordered to its engrossment by a vote of ayes 75, noes 15.

The bill provides that county or corporation courts — all its members having been summoned, and a majority being present and approving of the provisions of the act — it shall be lawful for them to appoint a general agent or storekeeper, not exceeding.--in number, whose duty it shall be to purchase and sell to the citizens of their respective counties such articles of prime necessity as the court may prescribe, and under such rules and regulations as the court may adopt; the sales to beat prices near as may be to the aggregate account of the prime coat, including transportation necessary expenses of sale interest on the money invested, &c. The agent or storekeeper, before entering upon the discharge of his duties, to take an oath for the faithful performance of the same, and to enter into bond with sufficient security, to be judged of by the court, upon which he may be prosecuted for any violation of the provisions of this act. The court of each county and corporation is further empowered upon the credit thereof, at any regular term, to borrow, for the purpose of carrying into effect the objects of the act, an amount of money not exceeding fifty thousand dollars at any one time.

The order of the day having been disposed of, the business pending at the hour it was taken up — for the sale of the Roanoke Valley railroad--was resumed, and, after further discussion, it was read a second time, and laid upon the table.

A message was received from the Governor, enclosing a letter from the Auditor of Public Accounts relative to apprepriations made to the Lunatic Asylum at Williamsburg; and a further communication in response to resolutions of the House in reference to the number and salaries of certain officers in the military service of the State; which were appropriately referred.

On motion of Mr. Rives, the resolution reported yesterday by the Military Committee relative to exempting from military service one deputy clerk in each county, and one deputy sheriff for every 12,000 inhabitants, was recommitted to the committee.
Mr. Burks submitted a resolution, which was agreed to, inquiring into the expediency of exempting from military service county surveyers.
On motion the House adjourned.

div3.head: The Way the conscription Works.
div3.p: --Within the last two months 1,463 men have been enrolled and conscribed by the enrolling officer at Atlanta, Ga., Of these, 19 were employed in the Medical Department, 51 in the Navy Department, 424 in the army works, 66 in the Quartermaster and Commissary Departments, and 845 exempted under the exemption act, leaving fifty one conscripts to be sent to the camp of instruction to go to the army.

div3.head: Fire.
div3.p:
--The alarm of fire about half past 12 o'clk Monday night was caused by the burning of the stable of Mr. Lottin M. Milett, on Church Hill.
It was evidently set on fire by an incendiary.
Its destruction was complete before the arrival of the fire brigade.

div3.head: Paroled.
div3.p:
--Wm. Rock, employed at Baltm's foundry arrested on Monday on suspicion of disloyalty has been paroled.
It was stated that he was originally from Norfolk, which is incorrect, as he is from Baltimore, and expects to prove at the examination that he has not been in Norfolk for ten years, nor out of this city for five months, having fied from Maryland when the draft was made and been here over since.

div3.head: Abolition prisoners.
div3.p:
--Ninety three Abolition sailors belonging to the Yankee gunboat Isaac Smith, who were captured in Stone river, S. C., on the 30th of January, arrived in Richmond yesterday, and were conducted to the Libby prison — Most of them were foreigners.
Among the names recorded were Antonio Watchguis and Alexander Mackerel.
On the same day there arrived at the above prison thirty-five members of the 5th Pennsylvania cavalry from Williamsburg.
They were captured about eight miles from Williamsburg on the 7th of February. Included in this batch were Captain Dupiat Haigleimalater, of co L; Edward Rhineneiler, 1st Lieut, co N, and Thes Little, 2d Lieut., do, and Privates Frederick Flasung and Chas Ulpitkait.
On the same day there also arrived twenty-six members of the 5th Pennsylvania cavalry from Gordonsville, who were captured in Stafford county on the 6th of February. The majority of these prisoners were equally as foreign, so far as regards names, as their brother Yankees.
In all, 154 prisoners were brought to the Libby prison yesterday.

div3.head: Prison Items.
div3.p: --The arrivals at Castle Thunder yesterday consisted of 26 soldiers, belonging various regiments, charged with desertion, sent to the prison to be forwarded to their regiments with all convenient speed M. Canovan, alies Kearns, was sent to Castle Booker; U. Gann was sent to the small-pox hospital; Tim Ryan was sent to his company; Renry Scean was sent to battery No. 2, from which he had deserved, W. B. Thomas and A. G. Sinclair, deserters, were sent to their regiments, Pat O. Nell, arrested as a suspicious character, was discharged by order of Major Gaiswold.

div3.head: City Jail.
div3.p:
--At the last meeting of the Council, on motion of Thomas H. Wynne, a resolution was adopted that the Committee on the City Jail take measures to cause the removal therefrom of all soldiers and other prisoners confined for offences against the Confederate States.
A large number of Confederate States prisoners have been confined for some time in the jail, and it is charged that they produce all the rowdyism that makes that place so famous in local annals.

div3.head: Arrests.
div3.p:
--The only parties arrested yesterday by the city police was John, slave of J. W. McKell, for having four bottles of whiskey in his possession supposed to have been stolen, and a white man too drunk to give his name.
Both of the subjects were looked up in the cage.

div3.head: City Stocks and small notes.
div3.p: --The Committee on Finance of the City Council has reported adversely to the resolution inquiring into the expediency of issuing fifteen cent notes; selling $500,000 worth of City Bonds for the purpose of investing the same in 8 per cent. C. S. Bonds, and selling the stock owned by the city in the various railroads.

div3.head: Interments in Shocks Hill Burying Ground.
div3.p:
--It appears by the report of the Superintendent of this Barying Ground that the interments for the quarter ending January 31st, 1883, were as follows: White males interred during the quarter, 220; females do, 64; still-born children, 5--total, 289.
Male negroes, 213; female do., 97; still-born, 6--total, 316.

div3.head: Error.
div3.p:
--In the police report of Monday it was stated that Mrs. Constance Vance, one of the witnesses, was an actress.
The reporter is requested to state that she is not a member of the theatrical profession, nor has the ever been.

div3.head: Court proceedings.
div3.p: --James Calfee, arrested by the police on a warrant charging him with threatening to cut out the heart of Wm. Jones," appeared before his Honor, and being unable to refuse the charge made by Jones, was required to give security for his good behavior.

Harvey Gordon a mulatto, was charged by his brother, Christopher Gordon, with entering his domicil on Sunday, and stealing two costs and one pair of pantaloons.
Witness deposed that he was at St. Paul's church attending Divine service when his brother entered his house and committed the deprudation complained of. The value of the property stolen was set down at $50, and was recovered by the aid of policeman B. 55.
An important witness being absent, the care was continued.

Ferry Dunnavant, a small lad, charged with an officers for which he had been admitted to bad by Judan Lyons, was brought in a Court by his security, who expressed a desire to surrender him because he had heard Dunnavant proposed to leave for the South, and leave him to pay the ball bond.
His Honor said he should have been surrendered to Judge Lyons, but that he would retain him until steps could be taken to do so properly.
Daniel Higgins, brought up for getting drunk and acting disorderly for the street, was admonished and discharged.

Michael Early, a seller from al the steamer Richmond, was charged with throwing down and choking Eudwell it Charles, a southern the affair happened he should commiting in default of security for his good behavior.
William slave of Faung found of possession supposed to have been stolen, not for their possession, was ordered a
Daniels Bisggies, arraigned for drank and disorderly in the street, was discharged — nobody against him.
News of , was fined $5 for riding his horse on the side- walk of street on Monday, and committed in default of surely for his good behavior.
Alfred Hosting worth the with stealing $490 in O. S. notes from Stephen, slave of Hobert than was examined and let off.
Balrick alias Betts was examined and to the Husting Court for shooting at and wounding Lafayetto Brooks with a pistol.
Wm. R. Warden, charged with obtaining two hogshends of sugar from Richard Cauthorn by false protences, worth $, was examined and sent on to the Hustings Court.

Mary McGen, charged with assaulting and beating Michael and Catherine McCarthy, was arraigned; but no witness appearing against her, she was discharged.
The Mayor ordered the issue of a warrant against the parties getting out the warrant, who counted the relation of mother and

div3.head: Yankee Regulation of slave labor in Louisiana.
div3.p: --The New Orleans Delta published the annexed order from Gen. Banks:

New Orleans, Jan. 29th.--[General Orders, No. 12]--The following proclamation from the President of the United States dated January 1st, 1863, is published for the information of the Government officers and soldiers of this command, and all persons acting under their authority.
It designates those portions of the State of Louisiana which are not to be affected by its provisions.
The laws of the United States, however, forbid the officers of the army of navy to return slaves to their owners or to decide upon the claim of any person to the service or labor of another.
The invitable conditions of a state of war invariably deprive all classes of citizens of much absolute freedom of action, and control of property, which loyal law and continued peace guaranted and secure them.
The forcible seizure of fugitives from service or labor by their owners is inconsistent with these laws and conditions of war.

Officers and soldiers will not encourage or assist slaves to leave their employers, but they cannot compel or authories their return by force.
Negroes who leave their employers will be compelled to support themselves and families by labor upon the public works.

To secure the objects both of capital and labor the Sequestration Commissioner is authorized and directed, upon conference with planters and other parties, to propose and establish a yearly system of negro labor, which shall provide food, clothing, proper treatment and just compensation for negroes at fixed rates, or an equitable proportion of the yearly crop as may be deemed advisable, and when accepted by the planter or other parties faithful service and subordination shall be enforced on the part of the negro by officers of the Government.
To secure their payment the wages of their labor will constitute a lien upon the products.

The Quartermaster's Department is charged with the only of harvesting corn on deserted fields and cultivating abandoned estates.
Unemployed negroes will be engaged in this service.
By command of Major General Banks.

div3.head:
Headq'rs Co. "I" 59th Reg. Va. Vols,
Manchester, Feb. 10th, 1863.
div3.p:
Deserted.--The following named men are deserters from my company, now stationed in Manchester.
If they will come and report to me at once, they will only lose their pay, but if brought back, under arrest, will be court-martialed and dealt with as the court may direct:

list.item: Geo. Martin, of Brunswick co.;
Wm. Chapman, a substitute;
Henry Donahob a substitute;
John Henry, a substitute;
J. T. Sliten, a substitute from Pittsylvania;
W. C. Noode, Pawhatan;
H. G. Dinwiddle.

div3.p: I will give $30 reward for the delivery of each

div3.head: Notice to .
div3.p: --The Beard for the 3d Congressional District is near Richmond.
All of conscript aye, who have been authorized to appear before the Beard for final examination, will report immediately.
div3.closer:
John A Coke, Capt. and Enroll'g Officer
3d Congressional District. fe 11--ts

div3.head:
Headq'rs 14th Tennessee Reg'r,
Archer's brigade, Jan. 17, 1863.
div3.p: List of Absenthes, without leave, from the 14th Tennessee Regiment, viz:

list.item: Private Allen Brown, Company A,
Private C. J. Kelly, Company A,
Private D. Sullivan, Company A,
Corp'rl W. W. Watts, Company A,

Private D. W. Johnson, Company E,
Private T. W. Marberry, Company E,

Private G. G. Robertson, Company E,
Private J. S. P. Wimberly, Company E,
Serg'nt S. D. Searboro', Company E,
Corp'rl B. A. Smith, Company, E,
Private J. H. Shemwell, Company F,

Serg'nt Thos. Davidson, Company G,

div3.p: The above-named members of this regiment are hereby ordered to report at once to this command, in person or by Surgeon's certificate, or they will be treated as deserters.
div3.closer:
By order of Col. Wm. McComb
W. E. Murford, Adj't. ja 21--6t*

div3.p:
Gentlemen in the list of "absentees without leave" from this regiment, (14th Tennessee) published is your paper there appeared the following names: P. M. Mitchell, J. C. Fields, H. H. Garriones, all of Co. A.
I now deem it but justice to those men to state that they were under treatment of Surgeons, with the proper certificates, but had called to notify the company committee of the fact; hence the mistake.

div3.head:
Camp battery no. 2,
January 31, 1863.
div3.p: last Chance for Absenters.--Parsuant to orders issued by Major-General G. W. Smith, all members of Company A, 10th Battalion Virginia Volunteers. Heavy Artillery, now absent, are hereby notified that if they report to camp by the 10th day of February no punishment will be inflicted, except the loss of pay for time absent.--Should they not report by the 10th day of February they will be considered deserters, and tried by the new Military Court now in session in Richmond and if found guilty, will be shot whenever apprehended.
div3.closer:
J. W. Barlow,
Capt. Commd'g Co. A, 10th Batt. Va. Vols.
Heavy Artillery. fe 2--9t*

div3.p:
Commissionner's Sale of Land, Slaves and other property, in the County of Hanover — Patsnest to a decress of Hanover County Court, entered on the 27th January, 1863.
I shall offer for sale to the highest binder at public auction at the residence of the late Robert Anderson, near Old Church in the county of Hanover on Friday, the 27th day of February, 1863, tract of land called "Panch's" lying about threee or four miles from the Old Church, contain one hundred Also sixteen they Slaves, consisting of men, women, and children.
Also, all the Farming Inplements and Housebrid Kitchen Furnished now in the possession of Mrs. Mary F. Anderson.

Terms.--For the slave and partiesable property cash will be required.
For the last, one cash put the balance upon a credit of one and tow years, with interest from the day of saft; or at the of the purchase.
If give bond and good security will be required, and retained the .

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 24, Number 36, page 2.

div3.head: The Crisis.
div3.p:
We have always been of that class who have endeavored to disabuse the popular mind, whenever it conceived any false hopes.
For this, we have sometimes been charged with discouraging our people, especially when we have told them plainly, and urged it upon them, that they had nothing to hope from foreign intervention, or from anything else save God and their own right arms.
Some people among us have been amazingly slow in discovering this patent fact.
But we are glad to see that it begins now to be pretty generally admitted.
The Ironsides at Port Royal, the immense fleet of transports, the huge army those transports carry, the tremendous preparations at Vicksburg, the heavy force of Rosecrans, the enormous army of Joe Hooker, are "fixed facts" which cannot be overlocked or gainsayed.
The near approach of a tremendous struggle is evident to everybody.
Recognition is no longer thought of; even the most sanguine give it up in dispair, as they ought to have done a year ago. The encouragement of the hope that it was coming, that it would be followed by intervention, and that intervention would put an end to the war, has done mischief enough already.
We hope it will not be allowed to do any more.

It is probable enough that in the multiplicity of attacks about to be made upon us, some of them may prove successful.
But unless all succeed our cause is still as hopeful as ever.
The invasion has been compared to the operations of an anaconda in the act of stifling his victim.
It is a good simile.
Wound the anaconda in any part of his body and you break his hold.
Defeat any part of this expedition and you destroy the whole.
Suppose the Yankees should burn Charleston and Vicksburg.
Of what avail would it be to them, if Hooker should be beaten here in Virginia as McClellan was last spring?
Of what avail would it be to the Yankees to nold Charleston and Vicksburg while we had an immense force within a day's march of Washington, with the whole Northern frontier laid open to our enterprises?

Let our people, then, be of good cheer.
The "anaconda" must succeed everywhere if it expects to accomplish anything worth fighting for. Partial success will not do. And even if they should succeed everywhere; if they should take Richmond, Charleston, Savannah, Mobile, Vicksburg, and Chattanooga, still we are not beaten as long as men survive to bear the banner of the red cross in the field.
We cannot afford to be beaten.
The consequences will be too terrible even to think of.--There are a thousand motives to render the war immortal.

lg.l:
"What though the field be lost!
all is not lost;
The study of revenge immortal hair,
And courage never to submit or yield,

div3.head: Correction.
div3.p: --In speaking, yesterday, of the Indian Princes, whom an English officer murdered in cold blood in a carriage, we are made to call them Indian "fiends," instead of "Princes."

div3.head: Type wanted.
div3.p:
--The proprietors of this paper wish to purchase 1,000 or 1,500 pounds of Nonpareil or Agate Type.
The highest will be paid.

div4.p: On Monday, February 9th, Gen. Francis M. Boykin, of Isle of Wight county, Va., in the 57th year of his age.
The friends and acquaintances of the family are requested to attend his funeral this day, (Wednesday,) 11th inst., at 12 o'clock, from Miss Bidgood's, on Main, between 6th and 7th streets. *
in Manchester, Sunday morning, the 8th inst. After a painful illness, Mary E Swann, of Powhatan, in the 44th year of her age.

lg.l: Dearest sister, thou has left us,
We thy less most deeply feel;
But 'tis God who hath bereft us,
He can all our sorrows heal.

div4.p:
The friends and acquaintances of the family are requested to attend her funeral at the residence of her brother.
Wm T Swann, in Manchester, on Wednesday morning, at 9 o'clock, without further notice. *
on Tuesday, the 10th, of scarlet fever, Walter A. Johnson, aged 3 years 9 months and 10 days, son of James H. And Adeline Johnson.

lg.l: Walter, again we hope to meet thee,
When the day of life has fied;
Then in Heaven with joy to greet thee,
Where no farewell fear is shed.

div4.p: His funeral will take place from Mrs. Stewart's, on 18th street, between Main and Cary. The friends of the family are invited to attend. *
In this city, on the 9th instant, of small-pox, Mr. Edward McCONNELL, in the 57th year of his age.
The friends and acquaintances of the family are respectfully invited to join the procession from his late residence on 3d street, between Byrd and Canal, this morning, at 11 o'clock.
On yesterday morning, of congestion of the brain, Edward Sterbins, aged 12 years, eldest child of Mary P and Capt. Albert H. Campbell, C S Engineers.
The funeral will take place from St. John's church at 11 o'clock A M to-day.
On Sunday night, after a very painful illness, Maria Angus, wife of John L Byerly.
The friends and acquaintances are invited to attend her funeral on Wednesday morning, at 10 o'clock, from her late residence, 27th and Franklin streets. 2t*
On Tuesday, 10th, inst, at a quarter to 4 o'clock P M, Mrs Mary Fordham.

The funeral will take place this evening, at 3 o'clock, from the residence of Mr. Wm Freeman, on 17th, between Marshall and Clay streets. The friends and acquaintances of the family are invited to attend.
On the 10th instant, Dean, only child of John T and Virginia H Salite, aged 10 months.

The friends and acquaintances of the family are invited to attend his funeral to-day at 3 ½ o'clock P. M, from the residence of his parents, corner of Clay and Gilmer streets, without further notice. *
In Baltimore, Md, on the 28th ultimo, John Alexander, Esq, an old and estimable citizen.

Mr. Alexander, had many friends in this State, where he passed many years of his life.
He was a K T in the Naval Lodge, F A M, of Portsmouth, Va. He was father of Capt. G W Alexander, A P M of this city.
Mr. Alexander was in his seventieth year.
On Sunday, February 8th, in Henrico county, of small pox, Mr. N. S. Shipman, in the 58th year of his age.

div4.head: Obituary.
div4.p: Died, on Sunday morning, the 8th inst, of small-pox, W H H Trammell, in the 23d year of his age.

Harrison Trammell, was a native of Merriweather county, Ga. He was a soldier, a member of company D 8th Georgia regiment.
He completed his education at the Oglethorpe University, Midway, Ga., in 1861.
But ere he had stood upon the threshold of manhood and sought to choose his vocation in life, the toosin of war sounded.--That decided his course.
Jealous of the honor of his country and her safely, he came to vindicate her glorious rights upon the field, and fell — but not in battle.
He died in Richmond, having come to this city to nurse a brother who was suffering with that horrible scourge which has hung the veil of mourning around many a hearthstone in our unhappy land.
After the most untiring devotion to that sick brother, he contracted the disease which took him off.

He was a stranger here.
Stranger hands nursed him and stranger hands buried him; but the rare example of fraternal devotion which he gave us, and which cost his life, won the admiration and love of the household where he lived so short a while.
May his friends and kindred take consolation in God, and strive to imitate his virtues.
He was a good soldier, a noble, brave, and generous man. But he is gone from among us. We will not forget him — the good that men do lives after them.
He died without a struggle, without a moan, a short while after daylight, ere the sun gilded the eastern hills his pure spirit had fled to that land where the drum is muffled forever, and where the tramp of armies is never heard.
W S L
Augusta (Ga) Chronicle and Sentinel, and Columbus (Ga) Sun please copy.

div3.head: Wanted.--to Quartermasters.
div3.p:
--A first class Quartermaster's Clerk, a native of this city, who has had 18 months experience, desires a situation in the same capacity, either in the city or field.
He can give the best of recommendations as to qualifications, etc. Address "J T N," Richmond P. O.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--for Sale--6,000 cords Wood in the tree, pine, oak, and hickory, 13 miles from Richmond, 2 miles from the railroad.
For further particulars apply to.
div3.closer:
W. F. Campbell, Broad st,
3 doors above 7th. fe 11--1t*

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--A Furnished House,in a central part of city.
Persons having one will find a good tenant.
Rent paid monthly in advance.
Address "A. B. C," Dispatch office.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--Gold Bullion and Gold Epaulettes wanted, at No. 33 Main st. up stairs.
The best price paid.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p: --Board in a private family by a gentleman for himself and two little boys, 6 and 8 years old. Address "Box 141," Post-Office, stating locality and price per month.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A healthy Puppy, not more than nine days old for which a liberal price will be paid.
Address "A. B," at this office.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--A man of experience to engage in the manufacture of Soap.
Apply to
div3.closer:
B. T. Harrison,
At Royster Hospital. fe 11--3t*

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--An active colored man, of good character, free or slave, to act as Porter.
Apply to
div3.closer:
R. R. Roberts,
Corner Cary and 13th sts. fe 11--2t*

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--Immediately, a Bread Baker.
Also, an intelligent young lady to assist in the store.
Apply to

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p: --At Madame Son's, three first-rate Milliiners and one Trimmer.
div3.closer: Mad. Son, No. 55 Main st. fe 11--2t*

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--By a young married gentleman, a native of this city, an unfurnished Room and Board for himself and wife, in a private family residing within fifteen minutes walk of the Post-Office.
References given and required.
Address stating terms, &c., "X," Box 528, Richmond P O

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--To rend, a small House, furnished; or 3 or 4 rooms, with the privilege of a kitchen, for a small family without children.
Address "A M J," through the Post-Office.

Commissioner's Sale of Land in Hanover county, 1½ miles from Hanover C. H. and one mile of the Virginia Central Railroad.-- to a decree of the County Court of Hanover pronounced on the 24th day of December, 1863, in the suit of Tally, & vs. Wingfield.
I shall proceed to sel upon the premises, on Wendesday, the 4th day of March next, the tract of Land in the bill mentioned, containing about 240 acres, adjoining the lands of J. S. Wingfield, Wm. F. Wickham, S. Wingfield, est, and others, and is the place on which Jos. Wingfield, dec'd, lately resided, about 3½ miles from the Court Houses, and one miles from the Virginia Central Railroad.
The building consists of a two story Dwelling, in good repair, and all necessary out buildings.
About one-third of the land is cleared, a large portion of which is in low grounds.
Of the wood land a large portion is in original growth.
The timber on the land will more than pay for it.
terms--One-third cash; the balance in 12 months, with interest from day of or the whole in cash, at the option of the purchaser, the title to be retained until the further order of the Court.

Administrator's Sale of 5,000 Cords of Pine Wood, 100,000 Feet on Seasoned Lumber, and one Steam Saw Hill.
Will lbe sold to the highest bidder, on Thursday, the 12th day of February, next, at the Saw Mill lately occuped by Rowland & Shriver, dec'd, about three miles from Cabn Cabin Point, Surry co., Va., the following property, to wit:

1. Horse and Harness, 2 yoke of Oxen, 1 Steam Saw Mill and Fixtures, Wagons, Carts, Carryloga; also, about 100,000 feet of seasoned Lumber, principally inch boards, and from five to seven thousand cords of Pine Wood, 5 Bugie's cross out Raws.
1 pair large Patent Balances, 30 bales of Hay, and all the Fixtures, too numerous to mention, necessary to carry on a well kept Saw Mill.
Persons wishing to purchase the wood or lumber, can have every facility for shipping to Richmond or Petersburg by the Norfolk and Petersburg Railroad, which is only a short distance.
Sale to commence at 11 o'clock A. M., when terms will be made known.

Eight or Ten Likely negroes will be sold to the highest bidder, for cash, at Powhatan Station, on the Richmond and Danville Railroad, on Saturday, the 14th of February, 1863.
The sale is for a division under a decree of the County Court of Powhatan in the case of Bass's administrator vs. Forces and others.

div3.head: Two Substitutes wanted.
div3.p:
--Wanted two Substitutes to join the army for the war. The sum of $1,800 each will be paid.
They must be over 45 years of age, and come recommended.
Apply at Room 103 Spotswood Hotel, or at Donnan & Co's office, on Shockoe Slip.

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p:
--Over 45 years of age, to serve in the Confederate army during the war. For a suitable man a liberal price will be paid.
Apply to Mr. Wm Long, or to Robert Young, at the Cigar Stand in the Ballard Hotel.

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p: --Over 45 years old. One of sound health and good moral character will be paid a liberal price by calling at
div3.closer:
Davidson & Chockley's,
Cary street, 3 doors below 13th st.
Richmond Va. fe 11--ts

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p:
--Any one washing to Substitute can get a liberal price by applying at the Linwood House.
Room 28 from 8 A. M. until 6 o'clock P M to-day.
Good references must be given.

div3.head: Substitute wanted
div3.p:
--To go in one of the best infantry companies in service.
He must be a man of good character will recommended, and over 45 years of age. A liberal price paid.
Apply to
div3.closer: Jas Williams, near old Market. fe--3t*

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p:
--A liberal price will be paid to a sound and reliable man over 45 years of age to go as a Substitute in Lawton's brigade.
Inquire at No. 111 Main street.

div3.head: Ran away--$100 reward.
div3.p:
--Ran away from "Wakefield." the farm in Hanover next adjoining Mr. Geo.
W Deswell's, on Monday the 9th instant, a negro man named Jim. Said negro is of dark complexion 5 feet 8 or 10 inches high, about 23 years old, and has a defeet in his rightways.
He was dressed in gray clothes, and had on either boots or wooden bottomed yellow shoes.
Before leaving he spoke of going to the Junction to get with our army and I especially request quartermasters and wagon masters on the lines of the Central or Fredericksburgs Railroads to keep a lock-out for him. I will pay the above reward for his apprehension and delivery in the jail at Hanover Court-House, so that I get him again; or to myself in Richmond.

closer.signed: Ex'r of Mrs. Judith Smith, dec'd.
